The "Made in China, sold on Amazon" community continued to grow in 2021 despite a crackdown on paid reviews and other violations that removed thousands of Chinese sellers from the platform, the US e-commerce giant said.

The number of new Chinese sellers added to Amazon recorded double-digit growth last year, Cindy Tai, Amazon.com's vice-president for Asia Global Selling, said in a video for the company's seller conference on Tuesday.

The number of Chinese sellers that achieved US$1 million in sales jumped 50 per cent year on year in 2021, and among that group, those reaching the milestone for the first time increased over 20 per cent, Tai said.

"The business of Chinese sellers on Amazon has not been impacted [by the crackdown on irregularities] ... there was no change in the ratio of Chinese sellers in Amazon's [overall] sales volume during the period, and the Chinese business maintained healthy and rapid growth," she said at the online event.

Amazon said last September it had closed about 3,000 online merchant accounts, backed by about 600 Chinese brands, amid a crackdown on consumer review abuses.

Tai said some of the big sellers targeted had repeatedly manipulated reviews or violated other rules, and ignored numerous warnings from Amazon.

Tai said Amazon would make it a priority to work with Chinese merchants to operate within the rules and good compliance was the bottom line for a brand's survival in any market or platform.

Amazon's crackdown, which began last May, hit some of the biggest Chinese brands on its platform, including Aukey, Mpow and Shenzhen Youkeshu Technology.

According to a report by Marketplace Pulse last month, Chinese sellers saw their market share drop to 33 per cent of Amazon's top sellers by the end of 2021, compared with 40 per cent at the beginning of the year.

Chinese sellers appeared upbeat at Amazon's online event this week. The US e-commerce giant encouraged the merchants to target emerging markets, such as Singapore and India, for growth. Amazon set up Asia's first training centre for sellers to sell globally in Hangzhou last September.

"We're very committed to the business in China, and even though there have been times where complexity has been added or there's been back-and-forth, we're going to work to overcome [these issues]," said Russ Grandinetti, senior vice-president at Amazon.

The firm's efforts to forge a partnership with Chinese sellers comes as global e-commerce platforms gear up to attract them. Walmart, which opened its marketplace to international sellers in March, added 6,000 sellers from China, accounting for 20 per cent of new sellers by the end of 2021, Marketplace Pulse data showed.
